name: Tenderfoot Requirement 1
description: Present yourself to your leader, properly dressed, before going on an overnight camping trip. Show the camping gear you will use. Show the right way to pack and carry it.

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 2
description: Spend at least one night on a patrol or troop campout. Sleep in a tent you have helped pitch.

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 3
description: On the campout, assist in preparing and cooking one of your patrol’s meals. Tell why it is important for each patrol member to share in meal preparation and cleanup, and explain theimportance of eating together.

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 4a
description: Demonstrate how to whip and fuse the ends of a rope.

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 4b
description: Demonstrate that you know how to tie the following knots and tell what their uses are: two half hitches and the taut-line hitch.

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 4c
description: Using the EDGE method, teach another person how to tie the square knot.

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 5
description: Explain the rules of safe hiking, both on the highway and cross-country, during the day and at night. Explain what to do if you are lost.

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 6
description: Demonstrate how to display, raise, lower, and fold the American flag.

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 7
description: Repeat from memory and explain in your own words the Scout Oath, Law, motto, and slogan.

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 8
description: Know your patrol name, give the patrol yell, and describe your patrol flag.

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 9
description: Explain the importance of the buddy system as it relates to your personal safety on outings and in your neighborhood. Describe what a bully is and how you should respond to one.

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 10a
description: Record your best in the following tests: Push-ups, pull-ups, sit-ups, standing long jump, 1/4 mile walk/run

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 10b
description: Show improvement in the activities listed in requirement 10a after practicing for 30 days.

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 11
description: Identify local poisonous plants; tell how to treat for exposure to them.

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 12a
description: Demonstrate how to care for someone who is choking.

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 12b
description: Show first aid for the following:

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 12b-1
description: Simple cuts and scrapes

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 12b-2
description: Blisters on the hand and foot

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 12b-3
description: Minor (thermal/heat) burns or scalds (superficial, or first-degree)

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 12b-4
description: Bites or stings of insects and ticks

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 12b-5
description: Venomous snakebite

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 12b-6
description: Nosebleed

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 12b-7
description: Frostbite and sunburn

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 13
description: Demonstrate Scout spirit by living the Scout Oath (Promise) and Scout Law in your everyday life. Discuss four specific examples of how you have lived the points of the Scout Law in your daily life.

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 14
description: Participate in a Scoutmaster conference.

name: Tenderfoot Requirement 15
description: Complete your board of review.

name: Tenderfoot
description: Tenderfoot Scout Rank

name: Boy Scout
description: Boy Scout Joining Requirements

name: Boy Scout Joining Requirement 1
description: Meet the age requirements. Be a boy who is 11 years old, or one who has completed the fifth grade or earned the Arrow of Light Award and is at least 10 years old, but is not yet 18 years old.

name: Boy Scout Joining Requirement 2
description: Find a Scout troop near your home.

name: Boy Scout Joining Requirement 3
description: Complete a Boy Scout application and health history signed by your parent or guardian.

name: Boy Scout Joining Requirement 4
description: Repeat the Pledge of Allegiance.

name: Boy Scout Joining Requirement 5
description: Demonstrate the Scout sign, salute, and handshake.

name: Boy Scout Joining Requirement 6
description: Demonstrate tying the square knot (a joining knot).

name: Boy Scout Joining Requirement 7
description: Understand and agree to live by the Scout Oath, Scout Law, motto, and slogan, and the Outdoor Code.

name: Boy Scout Joining Requirement 8
description: Describe the Scout badge.

name: Boy Scout Joining Requirement 9
description: Complete the pamphlet exercises. With your parent or guardian, complete the exercises in the pamphlet How to Protect Your Children From Child Abuse: A Parent’s Guide.

name: Boy Scout Joining Requirement 10
description: Participate in a Scoutmaster conference. Turn in your Boy Scout application and health history form signed by your parent or guardian, then participate in a Scoutmaster conference.

name: Second Class Requirement 1a
description: Demonstrate how a compass works and how to orient a map. Explain what map symbols mean.

name: Second Class Requirement 1b
description: Using a compass and a map together, take a five-mile hike (or 10 miles by bike) approved by your adult leader and your parent or guardian.*

name: Second Class Requirement 2
description: Discuss the principles of Leave No Trace.

name: Second Class Requirement 3a
description: Since joining, have participated in five separate troop/patrol activities (other than troop/patrol meetings), two of which included camping overnight.

name: Second Class Requirement 3b
description: On one of these campouts, select your patrol site and sleep in a tent that you pitched. Explain what factors you should consider when choosing a patrol site and where to pitch a tent.

name: Second Class Requirement 3c
description: Demonstrate proper care, sharpening, and use of the knife, saw, and ax, and describe when they should be used.

name: Second Class Requirement 3d
description: Use the tools listed in requirement 3c to prepare tinder, kindling,and fuel for a cooking fire.

name: Second Class Requirement 3e
description: Explain when it is appropriate to use a cooking fire. At an approved outdoor location and at an approved time, and using the tinder, kindling, and fuel wood from requirement 3d, demonstrate how to build a fire; light the fire, unless prohibited by local fire restrictions. After allowing the flames to burn safely for at least two minutes, safely extinguish the flames with minimal impact to the fire site.

name: Second Class Requirement 3f
description: Explain when it is appropriate to use a lightweight stove or propane stove. Set up a lightweight stove or propane stove; light the stove, unless prohibited by local fire restrictions. Describe the safety procedures for using these types of stoves.

name: Second Class Requirement 3g
description: On one campout, plan and cook one hot breakfast or lunch, selecting foods from the MyPlate food guide or the current USDA nutrition model. Explain the importance of good nutrition. Tell how to transport, store, and prepare the foods you selected.

name: Second Class Requirement 4
description: Participate in a flag ceremony for your school, religious institution, chartered organization, community, or troop activity. Explain to your leader what respect is due the flag of the United States.

name: Second Class Requirement 5
description: Participate in an approved (minimum of one hour) service project.

name: Second Class Requirement 6
description: Identify or show evidence of at least 10 kinds of wild animals (birds, mammals, reptiles, fish, mollusks) found in your community.

name: Second Class Requirement 7a
description: Show what to do for "hurry" cases of stopped breathing, serious bleeding, and ingested poisoning.

name: Second Class Requirement 7b
description: Prepare a personal first-aid kit to take with you on a hike.

name: Second Class Requirement 7c
description: Demonstrate first aid for the following:

name: Second Class Requirement 7c-1
description: Object in the eye

name: Second Class Requirement 7c-2
description: Bite of a suspected rabid animal

name: Second Class Requirement 7c-3
description: Puncture wounds from a splinter, nail, and fishhook

name: Second Class Requirement 7c-4
description: Serious burns (partial thickness, or second-degree)

name: Second Class Requirement 7c-5
description: Heat exhaustion

name: Second Class Requirement 7c-6
description: Shock

name: Second Class Requirement 7c-7
description: Heatstroke, dehydration, hypothermia, and hyperventilation

name: Second Class Requirement 8a
description: Tell what precautions must be taken for a safe swim.

name: Second Class Requirement 8b
description: Demonstrate your ability to jump feetfirst into water over your head in depth, level off and swim 25 feet on the surface, stop, turn sharply, resume swimming, then return to your starting place.

name: Second Class Requirement 8c
description: Demonstrate water rescue methods by reaching with your arm or leg, by reaching with a suitable object, and by throwing lines and objects. Explain why swimming rescues should not be attempted when a reaching or throwing rescue is possible, and explain why and how a rescue swimmer should avoid contact with the victim.

name: Second Class Requirement 9a
description: Participate in a school, community, or troop program on the dangers of using drugs, alcohol, and tobacco and other practices that could be harmful to your health. Discuss your participation in the program with your family, and explain the dangers of substance addictions.

name: Second Class Requirement 9b
description: Explain the three R's of personal safety and protection.

name: Second Class Requirement 10
description: Earn an amount of money agreed upon by you and your parent, then save at least 50 percent of that money.

name: Second Class Requirement 11
description: Demonstrate  Scout spirit by living the Scout Oath (Promise) and Scout Law in your everyday life. Discuss four specific examples (different from those used for Tenderfoot requirement 13) of how you have lived the points of the Scout Law in your daily life.

name: Second Class Requirement 12
description: Participate in a Scoutmaster conference.

name: Second Class Requirement 13
description: Complete your board of review.

name: Second Class
description: Second Class Scout Rank

name: First Class
description: First Class Scout Rank

name: First Class Requirement 1
description: Demonstrate how to find directions during the day and at night without using a compass.

name: First Class Requirement 2
description: Using a map and compass, complete an orienteering course that covers at least one mile and requires measuring the height and/or width of designated items (tree, tower, canyon, ditch, etc.).

name: First Class Requirement 3
description: Since joining, have participated in 10 separate troop/patrol activities (other than troop/patrol meetings), three of which included camping overnight. Demonstrate the principles of Leave No Trace on these outings.

name: First Class Requirement 4a
description: Help plan a patrol menu for one campout that includes at least one breakfast, one lunch, and one dinner, and that requires cooking at least two of the meals. Tell how the menu includes the foods from the MyPlate food guide or the current USDA nutrition model and meets nutritional needs.

name: First Class Requirement 4b
description: Using the menu planned in requirement 4a, make a list showing the cost and food amounts needed to feed three or more boys and secure the ingredients.

name: First Class Requirement 4c
description: Tell which pans, utensils, and other gear will be needed to cook and serve these meals.

name: First Class Requirement 4d
description: Explain the procedures to follow in the safe handling and storage of fresh meats, dairy products, eggs, vegetables, and other perishable food products. Tell how to properly dispose of camp garbage, cans, plastic containers, and other rubbish.

name: First Class Requirement 4e
description: On one campout, serve as your patrol's cook. Supervise your assistant(s) in using a stove or building a cooking fire. Prepare the breakfast, lunch, and dinner planned in requirement 4a. Lead your patrol in saying grace at the meals and supervise cleanup.

name: First Class Requirement 5
description: Visit and discuss with a selected individual approved by your leader (elected official, judge, attorney, civil servant, principal, teacher) your constitutional rights and obligations as a U.S. citizen.

name: First Class Requirement 6
description: Identify or show evidence of at least 10 kinds of native plants found in your community.

name: First Class Requirement 7a
description: Discuss when you should and should not use lashings. Then demonstrate tying the timber hitch and clove hitch and their use in square, shear, and diagonal lashings by joining two or more poles or staves together.

name: First Class Requirement 7b
description: Use lashing to make a useful camp gadget.

name: First Class Requirement 8a
description: Demonstrate tying the bowline knot and describe several ways it can be used.

name: First Class Requirement 8b
description: Demonstrate bandages for a sprained ankle and for injuries on the head, the upper arm, and the collarbone.

name: First Class Requirement 8c
description: Show how to transport by yourself, and with one other person, a person

name: First Class Requirement 8c-1
description: From a smoke-filled room

name: First Class Requirement 8c-2
description: With a sprained ankle, for at least 25 yards

name: First Class Requirement 8d
description: Tell the five most common signals of a heart attack. Explain the steps (procedures) in cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR).

name: First Class Requirement 9a
description: Tell what precautions must be taken for a safe trip afloat.

name: First Class Requirement 9b
description: Successfully complete the BSA swimmer test.

name: First Class Requirement 9c
description: With a helper and a practice victim, show a line rescue both as tender and as rescuer. (The practice victim should be approximately 30 feet from shore in deep water.)

name: First Class Requirement 10
description: Tell someone who is eligible to join Boy Scouts, or an inactive Boy Scout, about your troop's activities. Invite him to a troop outing, activity, service project, or meeting. Tell him how to join, or encourage the inactive Boy Scout to become active.

name: First Class Requirement 11
description: Describe the three things you should avoid doing related to use of the Internet. Describe a cyberbully and how you should respond to one.

name: First Class Requirement 12
description: Demonstrate Scout spirit by living the Scout Oath (Promise) and Scout Law in your everyday life. Discuss four specific examples (different from those used for Tenderfoot requirement 13 and Second Class requirement 11) of how you have lived the points of the Scout Law in your daily life.

name: First Class Requirement 13
description: Participate in a Scoutmaster conference.

name: First Class Requirement 14
description: Complete your board of review.
